components.label: HTML
components.content:
Label Buster

Label Buster is a step-by-step guide to help you identify information you need to create a food label that meets Australian requirements. At the end of Label Buster, you will generate:

  • a product sheet you can give to a printer to design a label for you
  • an example of what your food label should look like.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Food Standards Code) sets the standards for food labelling in Australia. Significant penalties apply in Queensland under the Food Act 2006 (the Act), for non-compliance with the Food Standards Code.

Did you know

Labels must have the same information whether you sell your product once at a market stall, or regularly to a supermarket.

Who can use Label Buster?

Label Buster is designed for small to medium food businesses. If your food has complex labelling requirements, such as infant formula, sports supplements or alcohol, the tool does not provide all the information you need, and you are recommended to seek professional legal advice from a food labelling consultant.

Before you start

To use Label Buster, you will need:

Up to 1 hour - if you are familiar with food labelling requirements.

Up to 2 hours - if you have never made a food label before.

You will need information about your food, such as:

  • ingredients
  • use-by or best-before dates
  • any storage conditions or directions for use

The questions marked with a * must be completed. Other questions are optional.

Did you know

Label Buster will provide you with food labelling information to help you to comply with the Food Standards Code. After you finish Label Buster, you will need to include other mandatory requirements for a Nutrition Information Panel , weights and measures , and Country of origin labelling. Health Star Rating is a voluntary scheme you can choose to add to your food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using Label Buster

  • Terms and conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

Warning

This tool does not meet all your legislative requirements, only those relating to the Food Standards Code. You will need to include other requirements on your food label, such as country of origin labelling.

It is your responsibility to ensure all the information on your food label is true and correct.

Queensland Health respects your right to privacy in using Label Buster. Any information you give will be handled by Queensland Health in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

No personal information is stored when you use Label Buster. For information about how Queensland Health protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see our website at www.health.qld.gov.au

Please note that our terms of use may change over time.

Label Buster is current as of June 2020 and shows information up to and including amendment number 192 of the Food Standards Code. It is recommended that you refer to the most current version of the Food Standards Code for full details and note any changes.

Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Label Buster
HTML
components.content:
About food labels

Select on the food label sections below to learn about labels.

|

Food labels must show the name of the food to help identify the food.

The name and description of the food must reflect its true nature. For example, strawberry yoghurt must contain strawberries. If the yoghurt contained strawberry flavouring rather than real fruit, then the name would need to indicate that it is strawberry-flavoured yoghurt.

If the name of the food does not reflect its true nature, then you must include a description of the true nature on the label. For example, Luke’s Hot’s Sauce (red chilli pepper sauce).

To help customers identify where food has come from or to use for a food recall when food is unsafe, a food label must include the following business details:

  • name of the business supplying the food
  • business address in Australia or New Zealand, or a description of the location, of the premises where the business is being operated. A postal address cannot be used.

The National Measurement Institute is responsible for making sure food is measured and weighed correctly, and that the food is labelled with the correct weight and unit.

For example, food labelled as being 500g should weigh 500g and use the metric system of grams (g), kilograms (kg), millilitres (mL), litres (L), etc.

Visit the NMI website for more information on how to comply with the laws around weights and other measures.

Food packaged with a shelf life of 2 years or less must show a date mark.

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Otherwise, a best-before date is required if the food has a shelf life of less than 2 years. Although it may be safe to eat the food after the best-before date, the food may have lost quality or some nutritional value.

Bread with a shelf-life of less than 7 days, can use a baked-for date or baked-on date instead of a best-before date.

The lot identification means a number or other information that identifies where the food was made and the batch it was part of. Often the date mark, name and address of the manufacturer meets this requirement.

Storage conditions
To keep food until its best-before or use-by date include storage conditions on your label.

Directions for use
A food label must have directions on how to use or prepare the food if needed for health and safety reasons.

A food label must contain a list of ingredients. The Food Standards Code has rules that describe how each ingredient must be listed, what it is called, and how it is formatted.

To help consumers avoid foods that are not safe for them to eat due to health conditions they may have, the Food Standards Code lists mandatory advisory statements, warning statements and allergen declarations that must be shown on a food label depending on the type of food and its ingredients.

The nutrition information panel (NIP) shows the number of servings in the package and the average amounts in a serving of food and per 100 grams (or 100 millilitres) of food for:

  • energy (in kilojoules)
  • protein
  • fat (including saturated fat)
  • carbohydrates (including sugars)
  • sodium

If a nutrition, health or related claim is made, the NIP must also show the amount of nutrient or substance. For example: the amount of calcium must be shown in the nutrition information panel if a claim about calcium is made.

There are strict requirements about claims that can be made and how they should be written on a label.

Nutrition content claims are claims about the content of certain nutrients or substances in a food. For example, contains calcium.

Health claims refer to a relationship between food and health. For example, calcium for bone and teeth.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Limitations of Label Buster

Foods with complex labelling requirements are excluded from Label Buster. The following questions will help you to work out if you can use Label Buster for your food.

components.legend:
Is your food:*
  • an
  • a ,
  • an
  • a
  • a drink base (solid or liquid) that is used to make any of the drinks above?
components.label: Field Set

Is your food:*
  • an
  • a ,
  • an
  • a
  • a drink base (solid or liquid) that is used to make any of the drinks above?
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label buster does not provide labelling information for these drinks. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.legend: Is your food a <button data-accordion-item="special-food" class="accordion-btn">   special purpose food</button >? <abbr title="(required)" class="required">*</abbr>
components.label: Is your food a <button data-accordion-item="special-food" class="accordion-btn">special purpose food</button>?
HTML
components.content:
Special purpose foods include:
  • Infant formula products
  • Foods for infants
  • Formulated meal replacements and formulated supplementary foods
  • Formulated supplementary sports foods
  • Food for special medical purposes

components.label: Is your food a <button data-accordion-item="special-food" class="accordion-btn">special purpose food</button>?
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for special purposefoods. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.legend: Is your food a <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="novel-food">   novel food </button> or does it contain an ingredient that is a novel food? <abbr   title="(required)"   class="required"   >*</abbr >
components.label: Is your food a <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="novel-food">novel food</button> or does it contain an ingredient that is a novel food?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
    A novel food is a food or component that does not have a history of human consumption in Australia or New Zealand. This includes food that is typically not considered food, or a food made from processes not previously applied to food.
</small>

components.label: Is your food a <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="novel-food">novel food</button> or does it contain an ingredient that is a novel food?
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for novel foods.

Novel foods require pre-market clearance before the food can be sold. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.legend: Does your food contain ingredients that are produced from gene technology, or is your food a <button data-accordion-item="modified-food" class="accordion-btn">   genetically modified food </button> ? <abbr title="(required)" class="required">*</abbr>
components.label: Does your food contain ingredients that are produced from gene technology, or is your food a <button data-accordion-item="modified-food" class="accordion-btn">   genetically modified food </button>
Does your food contain ingredients that are produced from gene technology, or is your food a <button data-accordion-item="modified-food" class="accordion-btn">genetically modified food</button>
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for genetically modified foods.

Genetically modified food requires pre-market clearance before the food can be sold. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.legend: Is your food an <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="irradiated-food">   irradiated food</button >? <abbr title="(required)" class="required">*</abbr>
components.label: Is your food an <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="irradiated-food">irradiated food</button>?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"
  >Irradiation of food is prohibited unless specifically permitted by the Food
  Standards Code and must comply with the specified conditions, using only a
  permitted source of radiation.
</small>

components.label: Is your food an <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="irradiated-food">irradiated food</button>?
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for genetically modified foods.

Genetically modified food requires pre-market clearance before the food can be sold. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.legend: Do you make a <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="nutrition-claims">   claim </button> about your food? <abbr title="(required)" class="required">*</abbr>
components.label: Do you make a <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="nutrition-claims">   claim </button> about your food?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  Claims are voluntary statements made on a food label and in advertising about
  a link between your food and health. For example, Gluten free, good source of
  calcium, organic, cage free.
</small>

components.label: Do you make a <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="nutrition-claims">   claim </button> about your food?
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Making voluntary about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.

Please note, that about your food has other requirements such as additional information in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

You can only continue using Label Buster if you choose not to make a claim about your product.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Food name and description

The purpose of a is to correctly describe what the food is. It cannot mislead the customer.

The Food Standards Code has rules on what you can name your food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Does your food name, or label, highlight an ingredient?
For example:
  • Strawberries in strawberry yoghurt
  • Wholegrain in wholegrain bread
  • A picture of a honey pot on a muesli bar

components.label:
Does your food name, or label, highlight an ingredient?Does your food name, or label, highlight an ingredient?
For example:
  • Strawberries in strawberry yoghurt
  • Wholegrain in wholegrain bread
  • A picture of a honey pot on a muesli bar
HTML
components.content:
Characterising ingredients

Ingredients which are mentioned in the food name are called The Food Standards Code requires the amount of characterising ingredients to be shown in the ingredients list.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Is your food one of the following:
  • (For example: salami, chorizo, pepperoni)

components.label:
Is your food one of the following:
  • (For example: salami, chorizo, pepperoni)
HTML
components.content:
Prescribed names

These foods have names that must be used ( ).

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Food with extra requirements

Some foods have extra requirements. Use the to find out what they are.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Business details

Food labels must include the business details (name and address) of the supplier on the label. A supplier is a business which packs, manufactures, sells or imports food. Business details help consumers, other businesses and government agencies know who to contact in the event of a complaint or food recall.

components.label: Business name
components.description: This is the name of the food business that is the supplier, manufacturer, packer, vendor or importer of the food.

components.label: Business Address
components.description: A business address is the street address, or a description of the location, of the premises, where the business is operating in Australia.  A post office box or similar is not allowed.

validate.customMessage: Nup, we need this filled out mate.

components.label: HTML
components.content: <label for="ev86lq">Business Address</label>

components.label: Can’t find the address? Enter it manually.
HTML
components.content:
Date marks

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Other food that should be eaten in 2 years must have a best-before date.

components.legend:
Does your food have a shelf life of more than 2 years? *
For example:
  • Apricot jam in a bottle that has been heat treated
  • Canned peaches
components.label: Field Set

Does your food have a shelf life of more than 2 years? *
For example:
  • Apricot jam in a bottle that has been heat treated
  • Canned peaches
HTML
components.content:
No date mark is required

No date marking information is required for a food with a shelf life of more than 2 years.

Manufacturers can choose to label this food with a packed-on date as a means of

components.legend: Is your food bread, with a shelf life of less than 7 days? *
components.label: Is your food bread, with a shelf life of less than 7 days? *
Is your food bread, with a shelf life of less than 7 days? *
HTML
components.content:
Best-before, baked-on or baked-for date

Bread with a shelf life of less than 7 days can be labelled using either a:

components.legend:
Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).
components.label:
Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).

Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).
HTML
components.content:
Use-by date

These foods must be labelled with a because they may become unsafe to eat after the use-by date has passed. A food may look, smell and taste ok but be unsafe to eat.

Best-before date

A is required for all foods with a shelf life of 2 years or less that do not need a The best-before date is the date up to which the food remains with good appearance, smell and taste, and keeps any qualities for which a claim has been made.

components.label: What type of date mark do you need for your food? *

values.label: <button data-accordion-item="date-mark" class="accordion-btn">       Do not need a date mark     </button>

components.label: HTML
components.content:
What is the date for the food?
The date will usually be in the of:
  • dd/mm/yyyy (e.g.: 15/3/2020) for food with a shelf life of 3 months or less, or
  • mmm/yyyy (e.g.: Apr 2021) for food with a shelf life of more than 3 months.

Leave this question blank if the food is not packaged or does not need a date mark.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Lot identifications
helps identify food. If using your date mark, leave blank or enter a batch number below.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Storage and use

Storage conditions describe how to keep food until its best-before or use-by date.

Directions for use are instructions for how to prepare the food so that it is ready to eat.

Storage conditions

Select the for your food. If your food has specific storage conditions to make sure it will keep until the best-before or use-by date, then you must include these on the label. Examples of some storage conditions have been included. You may select none, or one or more of these, depending on your requirements.

components.label: HTML
components.content: to

components.label: Keep refrigerated at or below temperature
Keep frozen solid until ready to use.
Storage Conditions output

'Keep frozen solid until ready to use.' : '' }} {{ data && data.storageConditions.otherPleaseEnter ? data.storageConditions.otherPleaseEnterDetails : '' }}

components.label: Directions for use
components.content:
Directions for use

Select the for your food. All food must include directions for the use if those directions are required for health or safety reasons. The directions for use are the instructions for how to prepare the food so it is ready to eat. Examples of some directions for use have been included. You may select none, or one or more of these, depending on your requirements.

components.label: Once opened, store in an airtight container.
Food should be drained before consumption.
This is a raw product and must be cooked before eating.
Cook until steaming hot in the middle.

Do not refrigerate or reheat once heated.
Care has been taken to remove all bones from this product, however some bones may remain.
Cooking / preparation instructions
components.description: Note: You must include cooking instructions that would make the food safe.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Ingredients

A food label must contain a list of ingredients that have been used to make the food. This is also known as the statement of ingredients.

components.legend: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (<button data-accordion-item="char-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">characterising ingredients</button> )?
components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (characterising ingredients)?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint">For example: strawberries in strawberry jam, meat in a meat pie. </small>

components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (<button data-accordion-item="char-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">characterising ingredients</button> )?
HTML
components.content:
Characterising ingredients

Food labels must show the percentage of the characterising ingredients in the food. The Food Standards Code provides details on how should be calculated and shown.

For example: The ingredient list would show the strawberries in strawberry jam as: Strawberries (23%).

components.legend: Do you use any <button data-accordion-item="comp-ingredient" class="accordion-btn"> compound ingredients </button>  to make your food?
components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> A compound ingredient is any ingredient that is made from two or more ingredients. For example: chocolate chips in a muffin, tomato paste on a pizza. </small>

components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Compound ingredients

If a food contains that contribute 5% or more to the final food, then all the ingredients and additives in that compound ingredient must be declared. If a food contains a compound ingredient that contributes less than 5% to the final food, then only allergens and food additives require listing.

For example: The ingredient list would show the dark chocolate chips in a muffin as: dark chocolate chips [sugar, cocoa mass, cocoa butter, emulsifier (soy lecithin), natural vanilla flavour]

components.legend: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an     <button data-accordion-item="alt-ingredient" class="accordion-btn"> alternative ingredient  </button> to make your food?
components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> This includes a food ingredient or additive that is replaced with another food or additive that serves the same function. For example: sultanas or raisins in a protein ball. </small>

components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Alternative ingredients

, including food additives, must be declared.

For example: The ingredient list would show: sultanas or raisins.

components.legend: Do you want to list an ingredient with a <button data-accordion-item="generic-name" class="accordion-btn"> generic name</button>?
components.label: Field Set
HTML
components.content:
Generic names may be used to describe the ingredient.

Cheese, cocoa butter, crystallised fruit, fruit, gum bases, herbs, meat, milk protein, poultry meat, spices and vegetables can be used as a generic name without any conditions.

, , , , , , , and have other requirements.

For example: Apple, pear and peach listed as “fruit” in a fruit pie.

components.label: Do you want to list an ingredient with a generic name?
HTML
components.content:
Generic Names

are specified in the Food Standards Code.

For example: The ingredient list could show the ingredients apple, pear and peach as either:

  • Fruit, or
  • Fruit (apple, pear, peach)

components.legend: Does your food contain any         <button data-accordion-item="food-additive" class="accordion-btn">food additives </button>?
components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> For example: Food colours, flavours, preservatives, sweeteners, thickeners, etc. </small>

components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content:
Food additives

The substance (including a vitamin or mineral) used as a food additive must be declared.

The Food Standards Code specifies how to list in the ingredient list. This includes a list of class names and codes to use for specific food additives.

For example: The ingredient list would show the yellow food colouring tartrazine as either:

  • Colour (tartrazine), or
  • Colour (102)

components.legend: Does your food contain any         <button data-accordion-item="exempt-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">exempt ingredients </button> that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • A substance or food that is used as a processing aid.
  • An ingredient of a flavouring substance.
  • An ingredient such as water or alcohol, that is completely removed during the manufacture of the food.
  • Added water that forms part of broth, brine or syrup.

components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
Exempt ingredients

do not need to be included in the ingredient list.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Enter ingredients in

components.legend: Enter each ingredient that is used to make your food in   <button data-accordion-item="order-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">     descending order of ingoing weight   </button> .
components.label: Enter each ingredient that is used to make your food in descending order of ingoing weight.

To change the order of your ingredients:
  • Click the button
  • Drag and drop your ingredient

validate.customMessage: Please enter at least one ingredient to the ingredients list.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
The ingredients should be shown on a food label as:

Ingredients: {{data.IngredientData.map((data) => " " + data.ingredient)}}

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Statements

Some foods or ingredients may be harmful to some people who are allergic or sensitive. These foods or ingredients must be written on the label no matter how small the amount and may also need a warning statement.

Allergen declarations

Select any food or ingredient in your food from the list below.

components.label:
Cereals containing gluten
For example, wheat, rye, barley, oats and spelt and their hybridised strains other than:
  • where these substances are present in beer and spirits; or
  • glucose syrups that are made from wheat starch and that:
    • have been subject to a refining process that has removed gluten protein content to the lowest level that is reasonably achievable; and
    • have a gluten protein content that does not exceed 20 mg/kg; or
  • alcohol distilled from wheat

Fish
Except for isinglass derived from swim bladders and used as a clarifying agent in beer or wine
Milk</br><small class="hint">Other than alcohol distilled from whey </small>

Soybeans
Other than:
  • soybean oil that has been degummed, neutralised, bleached and deodorised
  • soybean derivatives that are a tocopherol or a phytosterol
Sulphites added in concentrations of 10mg/kg or more

Tree nuts
Other than coconut from the fruit of the palm Cocos nucifera.
HTML
components.content:
The ingredients should be shown on a food label as:

The allergens should be shown on the food label as: Contains: {{ _.reduce(_.filter(_.toPairs(data.allergyDeclarations), function([key, val]) { return val }), function(acc, [key, val], index) { if (index === _.filter(_.toPairs(data.allergyDeclarations), function([key, val]) { return val }).length - 1) return acc + ` ${val}.`; return acc + ` ${val}, `; }, '') }}

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning and advisory statements

Select the food and ingredients from the list below to create and statements.

components.label: Milk, dairy and dairy alternatives
HTML
components.content:
Eggs and egg products

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Fish, crustacea and seafood

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: Raw fish that has been formed to look like a cut or fillet of fish using a binding system, without the application of heat, whether coated or not.
Raw fish that has been joined to look like a cut or fillet of fish using a binding system, without the application of heat, whether coated or not.
HTML
components.content:
Food additives and flavours

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: Contains one or more of the following substances, either alone or in combination, at a level of, or in excess of 10 g/100 g
components.description:
• lactitol
  • maltitol
  • maltitol syrup
  • mannitol
  • xylitol

components.label: Contains one or more of the following substances, either alone, or in combination, at a level or in excess of 25 g/100 g
Contains one or more of the following substances in combination at a level of or in excess of 10 g/100 g
components.description:
• erythritol
  • isomalt
  • lactitol
  • maltitol
  • maltitol syrup
  • mannitol
  • polydextrose
  • sorbitol
  • xylitol

components.label: Added phytosterols, phytostanols or their esters.
HTML
components.content:
Food containing alcohol

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: A food that contains more than 1.15% alcohol by volume
If selected, describe the nature of the process:
HTML
components.content:
Honey and bee products

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Kava and kava root

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: A beverage obtained by the aqueous suspension of kava root using cold water only, and not using any organic solvent
HTML
components.content:
Legumes and pulses

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: Milk, or an equivalent beverage made from soy, that contains no more than 2.5% m/m fat.
Evaporated milk, dried milk, or an equivalent product made from soy, that, when reconstituted as a beverage according to directions for direct consumption, contains no more than 2.5% m/m fat.
HTML
components.content:
Meat and meat products

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: Raw meat that has been formed to look like of a cut of meat, whether coated or not, using a binding system without the application of heat.
Raw meat that has been joined to look like of a cut of meat, whether coated or not, using a binding system without the application of heat.
HTML
components.content:
Milk, dairy and dairy alternatives

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: Milk, or an equivalent beverage made from soy, that contains no more than 2.5% m/m fat.
Evaporated milk, dried milk, or an equivalent product made from soy, that, when reconstituted as a beverage according to directions for direct consumption, contains no more than 2.5% m/m fat.
HTML
components.content:
Non-alcoholic drinks

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: A cola beverage that contains added caffeine
A food that contains a cola beverage that also contains added caffeine as an ingredient.
Bottled water presented that contains added fluoride
HTML
components.content:
Oils and margarine

Please select any warning and advisory statements that apply.

components.label: Edible oil where
components.description:
• the label lists the specific source name of the oil, and
  • the oil has undergone a process that has altered its fatty acid composition (e.g.: hydrogenation)

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your label information

Congratulations! You have completed all the steps in Label Buster.

Using your responses to each question, Label Buster has generated a product sheet and an example food label.

Label Buster is a brief guide to help you understand your labelling requirements. You may choose to get advice from a labelling consultant to make sure that your label complies with the Food Standards Code.

On this page, you will find:

  • Product sheet
  • Example food label
  • Legibility requirements
  • Exemptions
  • Download or email your summary
  • Need to update your label?

Product Sheet

You can take this information to a printer or graphic designer to create a label or use your own tools/templates. When creating your food label, you must ensure you meet the legibility requirements , such as minimum type size.

Food name and description {{data.productDescription || 'no data provided'}}
Business details {{data.businessName}}

Nutrition information panel A Nutrition Information Panel must be added to your food label. The Food Standards Australia New Zealand nutrition panel calculator can help you prepare your nutrition information panel.

Claims

Making voluntary claims about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.
Please note, that making a claim on your food has other requirements not addressed in Label Buster such as additional sections in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

Country of origin Information on how to calculate and display mandatory country of origin can be found on the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission website.
Health star rating Information on how to calculate and display a voluntary health star rating can be found at the health star rating system website.

Example of food label

Below is an example of what your label could look like, using the information you provided in Label Buster. Label components can be placed anywhere on the label you create. They do not need to be in the specific layout shown here. They may be displayed in any order or arrangement

{{data.businessName}}

{{data.addressDetails.addressLine3}}
{{data.addressDetails.state1}}

Legibility requirements

All required words, statements, expressions or designs provided on a food label must be in English, be legible, and be prominent so as to contrast distinctly with the background of the label.

Information in other languages is permitted, provided it does not negate or contradict the English information.

No specific print type or size is defined for general labelling requirements, however:

  • warning statements must be in a type size of at least 3mm (or 1.5mm on small packages)
  • a print size is prescribed in the Food Standards Code for some foods where a required statement must be shown (e.g. infant formula).

Exemptions

All of the food label information needs to be included on your food label, except for:

  • Food sold in small packages
  • Food with one ingredient

There are extra requirements for:

  • Food sold from a vending machine
  • Food sold in a hamper

Your label information summary

Download your label information summary. This summary includes your product sheet and an example of what your label could look like.

components.label:
If you prefer, we can send you your self-assessment summary by providing an email address below.

Email

Depending on your email provider, personal information may be transferred outside of Australia. By providing your email address, you voluntarily agree to this transfer.
HTML
components.content:
Need to update your food label?

If you would like to update details in your food label, such as different flavours or ingredients, you can go back and update your answers by clicking on the relevant step. You can then regenerate your label with these new details.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Notes

Use this section if you want to note any actions you've taken to improve your food safety

The information contained in this document is confidential and for the sole use of the intended recipient(s). This confidentiality is not waived or lost, if you receive it and you are not the intended recipient(s), or if it is transmitted/received in error. Any unauthorised use, alteration, disclosure, distribution or review of this document is strictly prohibited. If you are not the intended recipient(s), or if you have received this document in error, you are asked to immediately notify the sender by telephone in Australia 07 3328 9310 or email foodsafety@health.qld.gov.au. You should also delete this document, and any copies, from your computer system network and destroy any hard copies produced. If not an intended recipient of this document, you must not copy, distribute or take any action(s) that relies on it; any form of disclosure, modification, distribution and/or publication of this email is also prohibited. Although Queensland Government takes all reasonable steps to ensure this document does not contain malicious software, Queensland Government does not accept responsibility for the consequences if any person's computer inadvertently suffers any disruption to services, loss of information, harm or is infected with a virus, other malicious computer programme or code that may occur as a consequence of receiving this document. Unless stated otherwise, this document represents only the views of the sender and not the views of the Queensland Government.
